      4.   Recognition of fees, notices, and date of filing of the request for
site approval.
      5.   Recognition of other participating parties wishing to testify and
any other reports, exhibits, maps, or documents of record as filed pursuant to
section
5-8A-5 of this article. All participating parties, including members of the
public, intending to testify or cross examine must sign in or submit written
notification of that intent to the Village Clerk on or before the fourteenth
day prior to the public hearing, as set forth in section
5-8A-5 of this article. Members of the public who wish to provide oral comment
will not be allowed to present testimony or cross examine unless they have
registered as a participating party fourteen (14) days prior to the public
hearing per said section
5-8A-5.
      6.   The applicant and other parties may make an opening statement.
      7.   The hearing committee shall then hear testimony from the applicant
and any witnesses the applicant may wish to call. Upon the close of the
applicant’s testimony, other parties may offer expert witnesses and evidence
they may wish to present, subject to the profiling procedures of section
5-8A-5 of this article. These other parties may or may not be represented by
counsel. Upon the close of the applicant’s and other parties’ testimonies and
evidence, the Village staff may present any witnesses and evidence it wishes to
present. Members of the public, of record, as set forth herein, may then
present oral comment to the hearing committee. The hearing officer shall decide
the order of presentation of testimony and oral public comment subject to this
article.
      8.   All witnesses shall testify under oath. Testimony may include the
use of exhibits, provided they have timely prefiled such exhibits per section
5-8A-5 of this article. All witnesses shall be subject to reasonable
examination as follows: direct, cross examination, redirect, recross, and the
like. After all parties have presented testimony, reasonable rebuttal,
surrebuttal, and the like may be allowed at the discretion of the hearing
officer.
      9.   The hearing officer may propound questions to any witness or to the
applicant’s witnesses to clarify the record established by the participants at
the hearing or to bring out relevant information. The Village staff shall be
deemed a participant and a party to all proceedings and shall proceed last with
its case and cross examination if it chooses to present witnesses.
      10.   The hearing committee and Village Attorney may ask questions of any
witness following cross examination by participating parties.
      11.   Should any issues, facts, data, or other evidence arise during the
course of the public hearing which were not apparent or reasonably foreseeable
by a party from the request for site approval as filed with the Village Clerk,
such situation may constitute grounds for a recess in the public hearing for a
period not to exceed five (5) working days.
      12.   The hearing officer shall determine when oral public comment can be
presented, and shall not necessarily be limited to the end of the testimony
from all participating parties. Members of the public who wish to provide oral
public comment at the hearing shall register with the Village Clerk fourteen
(14) days prior to the date of the hearing, but shall not be precluded from
presenting such oral comment if they register with the hearing officer by the
end of the first day of the public hearing. The hearing officer may reasonably
limit the time for oral comment to be made.
      13.   Summary statements by the applicant and other parties subject to
limitations as imposed by the hearing officer.
      14.   Rebuttal statement, if any, by the applicant, subject to
limitations as imposed by the hearing officer.
      15.   Hearing closed. (Ord. 1068, 8-17-2020)
5-8A-7: PUBLIC COMMENT:
   A.   The Village Clerk shall receive written comment from any person
concerning the appropriateness of the proposed site. Upon receipt of any such
written comment, the Village Clerk shall date stamp same and shall file the
written comment and the postmarked envelope in which the comment is received.
   B.   Copies of such written comments shall be made available for public
inspection in the offices of the Village Clerk, and members of the public shall
be allowed to obtain a copy of any written comment upon payment of actual cost
of reproduction.
   C.   Any written comment received by the Village Clerk or postmarked no
later than thirty (30) days after the date of the last public hearing shall be
made a part of the record of the public hearing as described in section
5-8A-9 of this Article. The hearing officer and Village Board and Mayor shall
consider any such timely written comments in making its final determination
concerning the request. In the event that the thirtieth day falls on a
Saturday, Sunday or state or federal holiday, the next day on which mail is
delivered shall be considered the thirtieth day for purposes of this
subsection. (Ord. 1068, 8-17-2020)
5-8A-8: SITE APPROVAL DECISION:
   A.   After the public hearing and any continuation thereof, and at the
conclusion of the thirty (30) day comment period, the Village Board and Mayor
shall hold a review meeting for purposes of establishing its final decision
concerning the site approval request. The Village Board and Mayor may consider
the record in closed session pursuant to the Open Meetings Act provision for
adjudications, but the decision must be made in an open public meeting, with a
quorum as constitutes the Village Board’s customary decision making. In making
any final decisions, the Village Board and Mayor shall consider the hearing
officer’s findings of fact and recommendation. However, the Village Board and
Mayor are not bound by the hearing officer’s recommendation, but the decision
shall be supported by the record and shall be made in sufficient time following
the close of the hearing and public comment period so as to allow a final
decision at least one hundred eighty (180) days from the Village Clerk’s
receipt of the site approval request.
   B.   An applicant for local siting approval shall submit sufficient details
describing the proposed facility to demonstrate compliance, and local siting
approval shall be granted only if the proposed facility meets the criteria set
forth in Section 39.2 of the Act, as are now in effect and as may be amended
from time to time, which criteria are hereby adopted by the Village in
approving or denying the local siting application. Those criteria are set forth
in subsection
5-8A-2E of this Article.
   C.   The Village Board and Mayor shall consider the record from the public
hearing, from the public comment period, and the findings of fact and
recommendations of the hearing officer and shall make a final decision
concerning a site approval request within one hundred eighty (180) days from
the Village Clerk’s receipt of the site approval request. The Village Board and
Mayor may conditionally approve any request for site approval, provided such
conditions are not inconsistent with regulations promulgated by the Illinois
Pollution Control Board. Any determination by the Village Board and Mayor shall
be supported by the record. The meeting to review the record may be in closed
session pursuant to the Open Meetings Act provisions for adjudications, but its
decision must be made in an open public meeting. Decisions of the Village Board
and Mayor must be in writing, specifying the reasons for the decision, such
reasons to be in conformance with Subsection B of this Section. Such decision
shall be available for public inspection at the Village Hall, Village Clerk’s
office, and may be copied upon payment of the actual cost of reproduction.
   D.   No determination by the Village Board of a site approval request may be
reconsidered. (Ord. 1068, 8-17-2020)
5-8A-9: RECORDS KEPT:
   A.   The Village Clerk shall be responsible for keeping the record of the
hearing. The record shall consist of the following:
      1.   The request for site location approval as described in Section
5-8A-2 of this article.
      2.   Proof of prefiling notice given by applicant pursuant to Section
39.2(b) of the act.
      3.   Proof of notice of the public hearing given by the applicant
pursuant to subsection
5-8A-6D of this article.
      4.   Any additional public notices, such as of a prehearing conference.
      5.   Any documentation filed with the agency by the applicant regarding
the PCF, or the CD of such documents, as described in section
5-8A-2 of this article.
      6.   Written comments filed by the public and received by the Village
Clerk or postmarked within thirty (30) days of receipt of the filing of a
request for site location approval.
      7.   All reports, studies, exhibits, or documents received into evidence
at the public hearing.
      8.   The transcript of any prehearing conference.
      9.   The transcript of the public hearing.
      10.   Findings of fact and recommendations of the hearing officer to the
Village Board and Mayor.
      11.   The resolution containing the final declaration of the Village
Board and Mayor.
   B.   The Village Clerk shall be responsible for certifying all copies of the
record of the public hearing. (Ord. 1068, 8-17-2020)
5-8A-10: ADMINISTRATION OF FEES AND COSTS:
   A.   All expenses incurred by the Village in conducting the review of the
request for site approval, the subsequent hearing, and the site approval
decision and the costs and fees incurred in any appeal to the Illinois
Pollution Control Board and appellate court(s), including attorney fees, shall
be paid from the application fee as provided in this Article.
   B.   Upon termination of any proceedings under the hearing process, a final
accounting and summary of all authorized expenditures and reimbursements shall
be presented to the Village Board and Mayor.
   C.   Any portion of an application fee not required for reimbursement to the
Village for costs or expenses incurred by the Village under Subsection A of
this section shall be utilized by the Village for any purpose reasonably
related to solid waste management, annexation of land, recycling or any other
purpose authorized by law. Should there be costs and/or expenses in excess of
the amount paid by the applicant in the application fee, the applicant shall
bear any and all additional costs. When the application fee is reduced due to
costs incurred for proceedings under this Article and under Section 39.2 of the
act to Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000.00), the applicant shall be notified and
shall be required to post an additional Fifty Thousand Dollars ($50,000.00).
Any portion of the additional Fifty Thousand Dollars ($50,000.00) fee not
required for reimbursement to the Village for the site location approval
process shall be returned to the applicant. (Ord. 1068, 8-17-2020)
5-8A-11: WAIVER OF RULES:
In order to ensure fundamental fairness, compliance with the act, and to
protect the public interest, the pollution control hearing committee, by
majority vote of those present and voting, may waive any of the rules in this
Article. (Ord. 1068, 8-17-2020)
CHAPTER 9
FOOD ESTABLISHMENT REGISTRATION STICKER
SECTION:
5-9-1: Definitions
5-9-2: Registration Provisions
5-9-3: Sanitary Conditions
5-9-4: Restaurants
5-9-5: Mobile Food Vendor Registration Sticker
5-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following definitions shall apply:
FOOD: A.   Articles used for food or drink for man or other animals;
   B.   Chewing gum; and
   C.   Articles used for components of any such article, including beverages
and drink.
FOOD ESTABLISHMENT: A person or entity who stores, prepares, packages, serves,
vends food directly to the consumer, or otherwise provides food for human
consumption such as a restaurant; satellite or catered feeding location;
catering operation if the operation provides food directly to a consumer or to
a conveyance used to transport people; market; vending; location; conveyance
used to transport people; institution; or food pantry; and relinquishes
possession of food to a consumer directly, or indirectly, through a delivery
service such as home delivery of grocery orders or restaurant takeout orders,
or delivery service that is provided by common carriers.
   A.   Food Establishment includes an element of the operation such as a
transportation vehicle or central preparation facility that supplies a vending
location or satellite feeding location unless the vending or feeding location
is permitted by the regulatory authority; and an operation that is conducted in
a mobile, stationary, temporary, or permanent facility or location; where
consumption is on or off the premises; and regardless of whether there is a
charge for the food.
   B.   Food Establishment does not include an establishment that offers only
prepackaged foods that are not time/temperature control for safety foods; a
produce stand that only offers whole, uncut fresh fruits and vegetables; a food
processing plant including those that are located on the premises of a food
establishment; a kitchen in a private home, such as a small family daycare
provider or a bed and breakfast operation as defined in the Bed and Breakfast
Act that prepares and offers food to guests; a private home that receives
catered or home delivered food; a closed family function where food is prepared
or served for individual family consumption; or a cottage food operation. (77
Ill. Adm. Code 750).
EMPLOYEE: Any person who in the course of employment for another handles food
or drink during preparation or serving or who comes in contact with any eating
or cooking utensils.
RESTAURANT: Any eating or drinking establishment where food and drink is
prepared for consumption on the premises, as well as kitchens or other places
including bakeries in which food or drinks are prepared for sale elsewhere.
TEMPORARY RESTAURANT: A restaurant operating for a temporary period in
connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public picnic or public exhibition.
UTENSILS: Any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils, containers
or other equipment with which food or drinks come in contact during storage,
preparation or serving.
(Ord. 1101, - -2023)
5-9-2: REGISTRATION PROVISIONS:
   A.   Required; Application: It shall be unlawful for any food establishment
to engage in or do business in the Village without first having secured a
registration sticker therefor. Applications for such registration sticker shall
be made in compliance with the general provisions of this code relating
thereto, with Madison County’s Food Sanitation Program Ordinance Chapter 55,
and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or handled.
   B.   Fees: The annual Registration Sticker fee for a registration sticker
required by subsection 5-9-2A of this section shall be in accordance with the
following schedule:
      1.   For the sale of unprepared or packaged food or beverage other than
alcoholic liquor intended for human consumption, over the counter - fifty
dollars ($50.00).
      2.   For the sale of unprepared or packaged food, beverage other than
alcoholic liquor, or tobacco intended for human consumption, to be sold from
vending machines - fifty dollars ($50.00).
      3.   For the sale of unprepared or packaged food, beverage other than
alcoholic liquor, or tobacco intended for human consumption, to be sold from
vending truck or vehicle, five hundred dollars ($500.00) per vehicle annually
or daily as provided below in section
5-9-4 A2(b).
   C.   Penalty: Any food establishment found to operate without a registration
sticker may not continue such operation, and to do so is a violation of the
Village Code subject to the General Penalty for violation of ordinances and
each day that such violation shall continue shall be a separate violation.
(Ord. 1101, - -2023)
5-9-3: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
   A.   Maintenance Of Food Establishments: Premises used for the sale or
storage of food intended for human consumption must be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition. It shall be unlawful to permit any accumulation of refuse
or waste of any kind to remain therein for more than twenty four (24) hours,
and it shall be unlawful to permit any decaying animal or plant material to
remain on such premises. No dogs, cats or other animals, except for guide or
hearing dogs under the control of a handicapped person, shall be permitted on
such premises.
   B.   Unwholesome Foods: No person shall offer for sale or keep for the
purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for
human consumption which is spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for
human consumption for any reason.
   C.   Adulterated Foods: It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale, or
keep for such purpose, any food or drink intended for human consumption which
has been adulterated by any material harmful in any way, or which does not
comply with the statutes governing the same.
   D.   Flies And Vermin Prohibited: Premises used for the storage, preparation
or sale of food intended for human consumption shall be kept free from flies,
vermin and rodents.
   E.   Food Handlers:
      1.   All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food
intended for sale for human consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to
person and clothing.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or is a
carrier of any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in the
care of or preparation of food, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such
person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored, prepared
or sold, or to deliver such food.
(Ord. 1101, - -2023)
5-9-4: RESTAURANTS:
   A.   Registration Sticker Requirements:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant in the
city who does not possess a Food Establishment registration sticker from the
Village, which shall be posted in a conspicuous place. Only persons who comply
with the requirements of this section shall be entitled to receive and retain
such a sticker. A person conducting any mobile food establishment shall also be
required to secure a sticker, except as hereinafter provided.
      2.   Every applicant for a registration sticker to operate a restaurant
shall pay to the Village a fee or fees for each such establishment in
accordance with the following schedule:
         a.   Restaurants: fifty dollars ($50.00) annually.
         b.   Mobile Food Vendor Registration Sticker: twenty-five dollars
($25.00) per day.
   B.   Contagious Disease Control:
      1.   No person while affected with a disease in a communicable form or
while a carrier of such disease or while afflicted with boils, infected wounds
or acute respiratory infection, shall work in a restaurant in an area and
capacity in which there is likelihood of transmission of disease to patrons or
to fellow employees, either through direct contact or through the contamination
of food or food contact surfaces with pathogenic organisms. No such person
shall be employed in such an area and capacity in a restaurant.
      2.   If the restaurant manager suspects or should reasonably suspect that
any employee has contracted any disease in a communicable form or has become a
carrier of such disease, he shall immediately notify the state of Illinois
department of public health.
      3.   All employees shall thoroughly wash their hands and arms with soap
and warm water before starting work, and shall wash hands during work hours as
often as may be required to remove soil and contamination.
      4.   Hand washing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by
employees.
      5.   Hairnets, headbands, caps or other effective hair restraints shall
be used by employees engaged in the preparation and service of food to keep
hair from food and food contact surfaces.
   C.   Building Construction, Reconstruction And Alteration: All restaurants
which are hereafter constructed, reconstructed or extensively altered shall
conform in their construction to the requirements of this section for grade A
restaurants. Properly prepared plans for all restaurants which are hereafter
constructed, reconstructed or extensively altered shall be submitted to the
building commissioner for approval before work is begun.
(Ord. 1101, - -2023)
5-9-5: MOBILE FOOD VENDOR REGISTRATION STICKER:
   A.   A mobile food vendor is defined as a self-contained food service
operation, located in a readily movable motorized wheeled or towed vehicle,
used to store, prepare, display or serve food intended for immediate human
consumption. It shall include food carts, food trucks, and ice cream trucks.
   B.   A mobile food vendor registration sticker is required for any person(s)
wishing to sell food for human consumption from a food cart, food truck, or ice
cream truck.
      1.   Exceptions:
         a.   A mobile food vendor registration sticker is not required for
City-sponsored special events where a fee to participate is required or
assessed by the Village of Roxana.
         b.   A mobile food vendor registration sticker is not required for
private catered events held on private property when there are no sales to the
general public. Such sales must be limited to attendees or invitees.
         c.   Other special events by resolution or majority vote of the
Village Board of Trustees.
   C.   If a mobile food vendor operates more than one food truck/food cart,
then each such food truck/food cart shall require a separate registration
sticker.
   D.   Any mobile food vendor operating in the Village of Roxana shall be
properly permitted by the Madison County Health Department. All food trucks
shall be subject to the State of Illinois and Madison County Health Codes and
all rules and regulations promulgated by the applicable Health Commissioner.
   E.   Mobile food vendors shall obtain and either display or have readily
available for inspection at all times all State of Illinois and/or Madison
County Health Department permits required to operate their food truck/cart.
   F.   No food, food products, or beverages for public consumption shall be
kept, offered for sale, transported, or handled except in accordance with the
rules and regulations of the State of Illinois and the Madison County Health
Department.
   G.   If the State of Illinois or the Madison County Health Department
suspends or revokes their respective permits and/or licenses, then the
registration sticker shall hereby be revoked until such time as the State of
Illinois or the Madison County Health Department permits and/or licenses are
reinstated.
   H.   No food or beverage may be sold or given away in a glass container or
bottle.
   I.   Upon the submission of a complete application showing compliance with
all terms of this article and passage of the investigation, when required, the
mobile food vendor registration sticker shall be signed by the administrator.
   J.   No registration sticker shall be granted for longer than one year and
shall expire on the last day of December following its issuance.
      1.   The registration sticker for an annual mobile food vendor shall be
valid on January 1 and expiring on December 31 for the year in which it was
issued.
      2.   Registration Stickers for applications received throughout the year
shall be issued for one year from their date of issuance without proration.
      3.   All registration stickers and permits shall be either displayed so
that they are visible to customers at all times or kept within the confines of
the food truck/cart so that it is readily available upon request or inspection.
      4.   The fee for an annual registration sticker shall be five hundred
dollars ($500.00) as indicated in section 5-9-2 B(3).
   K.   Mobile food vendor registration stickers shall not be transferable to
any other applicant or vendor.
   L.   Every mobile food vendor shall indemnify and hold harmless the Village
of Roxana for all suits or actions brought against the Village for or on
account of any injuries or damages received or sustained by any party or
parties caused by the said vendor.
   M.   Proof of insurance of the vendor's public liability, food products
liability, and property damage insurance sufficient to protect vendor, property
owners, and the Village from all claims for damage to property or bodily
injury, including death, which may arise from the operations under the
registration or in connection therewith. Unless the rules promulgated by the
registration sticker administrator require a higher amount, such insurance
shall provide coverage of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per
occurrence. The policy shall further provide that it may not be cancelled
except upon thirty (30) days' written notice served upon the Village of Roxana.
A registration issued pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be
invalid at any time the insurance required herein is not maintained and
evidence of continuing coverage is not filed with the Village of Roxana.
   N.   Temporary mobile food vendor registration stickers issued to mobile
food vendors for either Village-approved special events or Village-sponsored
special events shall be valid only for the dates provided on the sticker, not
to exceed four consecutive days, and shall be event specific.
      1.   Each event shall require a separate application and registration
sticker.
         a.   Vendors who have paid for and been issued an annual mobile food
vendor registration sticker are not required to obtain a daily food vendor
registration sticker or temporary mobile food vendor registration sticker to
participate in a Village-approved special event.
         b.   The fee for this temporary registration sticker shall be twenty
five dollars ($25.00) as recited in section
5-9-4 A2(b).
   O.   Registered mobile food vendors are required to complete and submit the
Illinois Department of Revenue ST-2 Multiple Site Form on behalf of the Village
of Roxana for each applicable reporting period.
   P.   Location requirements. Unless otherwise authorized by rules adopted
under this chapter, mobile food units may operate only in permitted locations,
or when part of a special event authorized by the Village, or with the
permission of a private property owner and in accordance with all applicable
laws and ordinances.
      1.   No mobile food unit shall be permitted to operate in a location
where it would substantially obstruct a public way, impair the movement of
pedestrians or vehicles, or pose a hazard to public safety, and in no event
shall be within sixteen (16) feet from roadway intersections.
      2.   No mobile food unit shall park, stand, or operate in a location
which is adjacent to or within ten (10) feet of the property line of a
restaurant. This requirement shall not apply to a restaurant affiliated with
the mobile food vehicle vendor. A restaurant may manifest affiliation by
written request to the registration sticker administrator as part of the
application process or at other times when seeking to affiliate with a mobile
food unit.
      3.   No mobile food unit shall operate within ten (10) feet of the
address point of any fair, carnival, circus, festival, special event, or civic
event that is registered or sanctioned by the Village except when vendor has
obtained the necessary registration.
      4.   No mobile food unit shall operate within ten (10) feet of the
address point of public parks without first obtaining written authorization and
required registration from the Village.
      5.   No mobile food unit shall operate on private property within the
corporate limits of Roxana without first obtaining written consent to operate
from the affected private property owner.
      6.   No mobile food unit shall operate in any area of the Village that
the Village President, in consultation with the Administrator of Public Works
and Zoning Administrator, has determined is unsuitable for such operation.
   Q.   Hours of operation shall be limited to the hours between seven o’clock
(7:00) a.m. and ten o’clock (10:00) p.m., excluding special events referenced
in B(1).
   R.   It shall be unlawful to operate a mobile food service operation without
a Registration Sticker as issued by this section. Violators are subject to the
general penalties of the Village of Roxana, and revocation of any Registration
Sticker issued pursuant to the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Roxana.
(Ord. 1101, - -2023)
TITLE 6
POLICE AND PUBLIC SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
6-1-1: Created; Membership
6-1-2: Chief Of Police
6-1-3: Powers And Duties Of Department Members
6-1-4: Rules And Regulations
6-1-1: CREATED; MEMBERSHIP:
There is created a police department, an executive department of the village.
The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such other
members as may be provided from time to time by the village president and board
of trustees. (1981 Code § 2.20.010; amd. 2012 Code)
6-1-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Appointment: The chief of police shall be appointed by the village
president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. (2012 Code)
   B.   Powers And Duties: The chief of police shall:
      1.   Keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of
his department as may be required by statute or ordinance.
      2.   Be responsible for the performance by the police department of all
its functions, and all persons who are members of the department shall serve
subject to the orders of the chief of police. (1981 Code § 2.20.040; amd. 2012
Code)
      3.   Be custodian of all lost, abandoned or stolen property in the
village. (1981 Code § 2.20.050)
6-1-3: POWERS AND DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
   A.   It is the duty of the members of the police department to see to the
enforcement of all provisions of this code and other ordinances of the village,
and of all statutes effective in the village, and to preserve order and to
prevent infractions of the law and to arrest violators thereof. Every member of
the police department is declared to be a conservator of the peace. (1981 Code
§ 2.20.020)
   B.   It is the duty of every member of the police department to conduct
himself in a proper and law abiding manner and to avoid the use of unnecessary
force. (1981 Code § 2.20.030)
6-1-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The chief of police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the
guidance of the members of the department as he shall see fit. Such rules, when
approved by the village president and board of trustees, shall be binding on
the members. (1981 Code § 2.20.050)
CHAPTER 2
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
6-2-1: Composition; Appointment Of Department Members
6-2-2: Volunteer Department
6-2-3: Command At Fires And Training Sessions; Volunteers To Carry
Identification
6-2-4: Unauthorized Use Of Fire Apparatus
6-2-1: COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
The fire department of the Village shall consist of the Village President, the
Fire Chief, the Deputy Fire Chief, the Fire Captain, the Engineer, Firefighter,
and not exceeding fifteen (15) volunteer firefighters. The Fire Chief, Deputy
Fire Chief and Fire Captain shall be appointed by the Village President with
the advice and consent of the board of trustees. (Ord. 778, 2-19-2001; amd.
2012 Code; Ord. 1116, 1-15-2024)
6-2-2: VOLUNTEER DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Residency: The paid-on-call volunteer firefighters shall be divided as
equally as may be possible throughout the various areas of the village. Paid-
on-call Volunteer firefighters shall reside either within: 1) the corporate
limits of the village, 2) the areas within which the village has a contract to
provide firefighting or emergency services, or 3) a 7-mile radius from the
principal fire station serving the fire department of the village of Roxana,
excluding therefrom the state of Missouri.
   B.   Constitution And Bylaws: The volunteer fire department shall maintain a
constitution and bylaws as they believe appropriate. Prior to the amendment of
the constitution and bylaws, the volunteers shall submit the proposed changes
to the village president, village board of trustees, fire chief and village
attorney for their review and comment.
   C.   Selection: The volunteer firefighters shall be chosen by the volunteer
fire department, having due regard to the physical or mental qualifications of
the applicants. Prior to their final acceptance by the volunteer fire
department, the applicants shall be examined by the fire chief regarding their
firefighting and emergency response skills. Upon completion of the probationary
period and final approval by the volunteer fire department, the applicants
shall be sworn in by the village president in the presence of the village board
of trustees.
   D.   Tenure And Discipline: Each volunteer firefighter shall hold his or her
position at the pleasure of the volunteer fire department acting in conjunction
with its constitution and bylaws. Each volunteer firefighter shall be subject
to discipline, including suspension or expulsion, as provided by the
constitution and bylaws of the volunteer fire department.
   E.   Membership And Officers: The volunteer firefighters shall be members of
the volunteer fire department. The village president and members of the board
of trustees cannot be an elective officer of the volunteer fire department. The
elective officers shall include a president, vice president, assistant chief,
secretary and treasurer, who shall perform the usual duties pertaining to such
offices. The secretary shall keep record of attendance of volunteer
firefighters at practices, fires and meetings, and shall certify to the village
president and board of trustees the names of the volunteer firefighters
entitled to compensation. These elective officers may be paid for their service
as determined by the volunteers.
   F.   Compensation: The volunteer firefighters shall be compensated for their
services. The village president and board of trustees shall determine the rate
of compensation. The volunteer fire department may also schedule activities and
training for which the volunteers will not be compensated. The secretary of the
volunteer fire department shall determine the individual amounts due to each
volunteer firefighter in accordance with the bylaws and rules of that body and
provide that information to the village. Although the volunteer firefighters
are not village employees, the village shall pay these amounts directly to the
firefighters. Further, the village shall issue W-2 forms, and thus, the village
shall withhold amounts required by state or federal law. Payment in this manner
shall not qualify the volunteer firefighters for benefits due village employees
such as vacation or health insurance. Volunteer firefighters shall be entitled
to other benefits defined by law such as workers’ compensation and death
benefits, and eligibility for those benefits shall be determined by law.
   G.   Expenses Of Department: The expenses incurred by the volunteer fire
department shall be submitted at such regular times as the secretary of the
volunteer fire department shall determine. This shall include, but not limited
to, the reimbursement of death benefits paid, monthly meeting expenses and such
other expenses as may be incurred. Prior to its being approved by the village
board, such reimbursement statement shall be submitted to the fire chief for
review. The village president and board of trustees may determine an amount to
be paid as regular monthly meeting expenses. (Ord. 778, 2-19-2001; amd. Ord.
932, 8-6-2012, Ord. 1106, 10-2-2023)
6-2-3: COMMAND AT FIRES AND TRAINING SESSIONS; VOLUNTEERS TO CARRY
IDENTIFICATION:
   A.   The fire chief, or a regular firefighter when the fire chief is absent,
shall be in command of the fire or emergency scene. Fire scenes and emergency
scenes include the travel to and from such scenes and the related cleanup and
take down activities.
   B.   When training is called by the fire chief or the chief's designee, the
fire chief or the chief's designee shall be in command of such training.
   C.   When a volunteer firefighter is on duty, he or she shall carry an
appropriate identification furnished by the volunteer fire department.
   D.   Whoever wilfully violates any part of this section, or absents himself
or herself from any practice, fire or other duty assigned to such firefighter
without reasonable cause, shall be subject to such penalty as the fire chief
may determine to be appropriate. This may include immediate removal or
reassignment of duty. Additional disciplinary action may include suspension or
discharge from the department according to the rules described herein. (Ord.
778, 2-19-2001)
6-2-4: UNAUTHORIZED USE OF FIRE APPARATUS:
   A.   No person shall use any fire apparatus for any private purpose
whatever, nor, without authority, remove the same from its place of deposit,
nor shall any person having charge of any fire apparatus permit the same to be
used for any private purpose.
   B.   Any volunteer firefighter seeking to use any fire apparatus for a
parade, educational, public relations or other similar purpose shall first
obtain the consent of the fire chief or the chief's designee.
   C.   In addition to any other remedy provided by law, any person who
violates this section shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 778, 2-19-2001)
CHAPTER 3
EMERGENCIES
ARTICLE A. EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY
SECTION:
6-3A-1: Created; Purpose
6-3A-2: Coordinator
6-3A-3: Oath Of Office
6-3A-4: Functions
6-3A-5: Service As Mobile Support Team
6-3A-6: Mutual Aid Agreements
6-3A-7: Emergency Action
6-3A-8: Compensation
6-3A-9: Reimbursement By State
6-3A-10: Purchases And Expenditures
6-3A-11: Appropriation; Tax Levy
6-3A-1: CREATED; PURPOSE:
There is hereby created the village emergency services and disaster agency
(hereinafter "village ESDA") to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury
or damage resulting from disaster caused by the explosion of atomic or other
means from without or by means of sabotage or other disloyal actions within, or
from fire, flood, earthquake, telecommunications failure or other natural or
technological causes, in accordance with the Illinois emergency management act
1 . (Ord. 501, 1-5-1987; amd. 2012 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.
6-3A-2: COORDINATOR:
   A.   The mayor shall appoint, by and with the consent of the board of
trustees, the coordinator of the village ESDA. The person so appointed shall
assume the duties as the coordinator of the village ESDA following appointment
and confirmation and after subscribing to the oath as set forth in section
6-3A-3 of this article. The coordinator shall continue to serve until a
successor coordinator is appointed, confirmed and properly subscribes to the
required oath.
   B.   The mayor shall appoint, by and with the consent of the board of
trustees, a deputy coordinator of the village ESDA who shall serve temporarily
in the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability of the coordinator
to serve. The deputy coordinator shall perform such tasks and functions as
assigned by the coordinator from time to time.
   C.   The coordinator, or in his absence, the deputy coordinator, shall have
the direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training, and
operation of the village ESDA, subject to the direction and control of the
village president as provided by statute. (Ord. 912, 4-4-2011)
6-3A-3: OATH OF OFFICE:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the village ESDA
organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following
oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator:
I,                 , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and
defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United
States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory,
institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all
enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any
mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully
discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or
affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any
political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government
of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during
such time as I am affiliated with the Village ESDA organization, I will not
advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that
advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State
by force or violence.
(Ord. 501, 1-5-1987)
6-3A-4: FUNCTIONS:
The village ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions within the village as shall
be prescribed in and by the state emergency management agency (hereinafter
"state EMA") plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules
and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition shall
perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to
any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality, or
quasi- municipality entered into as provided in the state EMA act. (Ord. 501,
1-5-1987; amd. 2012 Code)
6-3A-5: SERVICE AS MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
   A.   All or any members of the village ESDA organization may be designated
as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the state EMA as
provided by law. (Ord. 501, 1-5-1987; amd. 2012 Code)
   B.   The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the
coordinator of the village ESDA organization. The coordinator may be the leader
of such mobile support team.
   C.   Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or
officer while serving on call to duty by the governor, or the state director,
shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights, and
immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a
paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, shall receive from
the state reasonable compensation as provided by law. (Ord. 501, 1-5-1987)
6-3A-6: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS:
The coordinator of the village ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with
other cities or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement
shall be effective until it has been approved by the village president, the
board of trustees and the director of the state EMA. (Ord. 501, 1-5-1987; amd.
2012 Code)
6-3A-7: EMERGENCY ACTION:
If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of
actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state
of Illinois of an explosion of atomic or other means from without or by means
of sabotage or other disloyal actions within, or from fire, flood, earthquake,
telecommunications failure or other natural or technological causes, it shall
be the duty of the village ESDA to cooperate fully with the state EMA and with
the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (Ord. 501,
1-5-1987; amd. 2012 Code)
6-3A-8: COMPENSATION:
Members of the village ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the village,
if called for training by the state director of EMA, shall receive for the time
spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position
held; members who are not such village employees or officers shall receive for
such training time such compensation as may be established by the village
president. (Ord. 501, 1-5-1987; amd. 2012 Code)
6-3A-9: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE:
The state treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any
reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training
members of the village ESDA as prescribed by the director of the state EMA,
compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team
while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or
director of the state EMA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made
by the state incident to ESDA activities as provided by law. (Ord. 501, 1-5-
1987; amd. 2012 Code)
6-3A-10: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
   A.   The village president or, in his absence or inability to serve, the
president pro tem of the village board of trustees, may, on recommendation of
the village coordinator of ESDA, authorize any purchase of contracts necessary
to place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting
from the explosion of atomic or other means from without or by means of
sabotage or other disloyal actions within, or from fire, flood, earthquake,
telecommunications failure or other natural or technological causes.
   B.   In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the village coordinator
of ESDA is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services,
supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view
of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities
normally prescribed by law pertaining to village contracts or obligations, as
authorized by the state EMA act; provided, that if the village board of
trustees meets at such time, the village coordinator of ESDA shall act subject
to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. (Ord. 501, 1-5-1987;
amd. 2012 Code)
6-3A-11: APPROPRIATION; TAX LEVY:
The board of trustees may make an appropriation for ESDA purposes in the manner
provided by law, and may levy, in addition, for ESDA purposes only, a tax not
to exceed five cents ($0.05) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the assessed
value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by
the state EMA act; however, that amount collectible under such levy shall in no
event exceed twenty five cents ($0.25) per capita. (Ord. 501, 1-5-1987; amd.
2012 Code)
ARTICLE B. CIVIL EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
6-3B-1: Definitions
6-3B-2: Declaration Of Emergency
6-3B-3: Curfew
6-3B-4: Executive Orders; Duration Of Emergency
6-3B-5: Provisions Not Exclusive
6-3B-1: DEFINITIONS:
CIVIL EMERGENCY:
   A.   Any natural disaster or manmade calamity, including flood,
conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion, within the corporate
limits of the village, resulting in the death or injury of persons or the
destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be
taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare; or
   B.   A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or
violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to
execute by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority of law.
CURFEW: A prohibition against any person or persons walking, running,
loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public
property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the village, except
officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty
with reference to said civil emergency. (Ord. 776, 1-2-2001)
6-3B-2: DECLARATION OF EMERGENCY:
Whenever an emergency, as defined in section
6-3B-1 of this article, exists, the village president shall declare the
existence by means of a written declaration setting forth the facts which
constitute the emergency. In the absence of the village president, the village
president pro tem shall act in the president's place. (Ord. 776, 1-2-2001)
6-3B-3: CURFEW:
After proclamation of a civil emergency by the village president, he or she may
order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the village or
to the village as a whole as the village president deems advisable, and
applicable during such hours of the day or night as he or she deems necessary
in the interest of the public safety and welfare. (Ord. 776, 1-2-2001)
6-3B-4: EXECUTIVE ORDERS; DURATION OF EMERGENCY:
   A.   After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the village president may
also, in the interest of public safety and welfare, make any and all of the
following orders:
      1.   Order the closing of all retail businesses wherein the consumption
or sale of intoxicating liquor, beer or wine is permitted.
      2.   Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any
wholesaler or retailer.
      3.   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away
gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container
other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle.
      4.   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or
giving away of any firearms, or ammunition of any character whatsoever.
      5.   Order the closure of any retail or other business necessary for the
protection of the public. However, refinery or heavy industrial operations
shall not be shut down without consultation with the appropriate environmental
protection agencies and an order of court. Such order shall not be obtained
without prior notice to the refinery or heavy industrial operation.
      6.   Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the
protection of life and property.
   B.   The proclamation herein authorized shall be effective for a period of
forty eight (48) hours unless sooner terminated by a proclamation of the
village president indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists. The
village president shall have the power to reproclaim the existence of a civil
emergency at the end of each forty eight (48) hour period during the time the
said civil emergency exists.
   C.   Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the chief of police
(or the chief's designee) shall notify the news media serving the village.
(Ord. 776, 1-2-2001)
6-3B-5: PROVISIONS NOT EXCLUSIVE:
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to impair the powers
contained in this code giving powers to the police and fire departments, but
shall be construed together with existing ordinances now in effect for the
safety and welfare of the citizens of the village. (Ord. 776, 1-2-2001)
ARTICLE B. CIVIL EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
6-3B-1: Definitions
6-3B-2: Declaration Of Emergency
6-3B-3: Curfew
6-3B-4: Executive Orders; Duration Of Emergency
6-3B-5: Provisions Not Exclusive
6-3B-1: DEFINITIONS:
CIVIL EMERGENCY:
   A.   Any natural disaster or manmade calamity, including flood,
conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion, within the corporate
limits of the village, resulting in the death or injury of persons or the
destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be
taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare; or
   B.   A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or
violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to
execute by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority of law.
CURFEW: A prohibition against any person or persons walking, running,
loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public
property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the village, except
officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty
with reference to said civil emergency. (Ord. 776, 1-2-2001)
6-3B-2: DECLARATION OF EMERGENCY:
Whenever an emergency, as defined in section
6-3B-1 of this article, exists, the village president shall declare the
existence by means of a written declaration setting forth the facts which
constitute the emergency. In the absence of the village president, the village
president pro tem shall act in the president's place. (Ord. 776, 1-2-2001)
6-3B-3: CURFEW:
After proclamation of a civil emergency by the village president, he or she may
order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the village or

applicable during such hours of the day or night as he or she deems necessary
