   C.   Nonliability Of Village: The village shall not be held liable for
damages in any action brought by the registered owner, former registered owner
or other legal representative, or by any person, as a result of towing and
storage of said motor vehicle.
   D.   Notice Of Impoundment: Whenever a vehicle has been removed as provided
herein, the police department shall cause notice to the owner to be given as
provided in subsections 7-2A-2B and C of this article. (1981 Code § 10.56.050)
7-2A-4: REDEMPTION OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLE:
Before the owner or person entitled to possession of any impounded vehicle
shall be permitted to remove the same, he shall furnish evidence of his
identity, ownership of the vehicle and his right to possession thereof and,
upon delivery, shall sign a receipt for the vehicle. (1981 Code § 10.56.060)
7-2A-5: ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL:
The chief of police shall have the responsibility of enforcing this article,
including the authorization and selection of reputable towing services. (1981
Code § 10.56.050)
CHAPTER 3
TRAFFIC SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Installation
7-3-2: Specifications
7-3-3: Obedience Required
7-3-4: Placement Prerequisite To Enforcement
7-3-5: Traffic Lanes
7-3-6: Crosswalks
7-3-7: Unauthorized Signs, Signals And Markings
7-3-8: Damage To Devices Prohibited
7-3-1: INSTALLATION:
The village traffic engineer shall place and maintain traffic control signs,
signals and devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances of the
village to make effective the provisions of said ordinances, and may place and
maintain such additional traffic control devices as he may deem necessary to
regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of the village or under state law
or to guide or warn traffic. (1981 Code § 10.12.010)
7-3-2: SPECIFICATIONS:
All traffic control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the manual and
specifications approved by the state highway commission or resolution or
ordinance adopted by the village president and board of trustees. All signs and
signals required under this title for a particular purpose shall, so far as
practicable, be uniform as to type and location throughout the village. All
traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of
state law or this title shall be official traffic control devices. (1981 Code §
10.12.020; amd. 2012 Code)
7-3-3: OBEDIENCE REQUIRED:
The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any traffic control
device applicable thereto placed in accordance with the provisions of this
title unless otherwise directed by traffic or police officers, subject to the
exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in this title.
(1981 Code § 10.12.030)
7-3-4: PLACEMENT PREREQUISITE TO ENFORCEMENT:
No provision of this title for which signs are required shall be enforced
against an alleged violator if, at the time and place of the alleged violation,
an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen
by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state
that signs are required, such section shall be effective even though no signs
are erected or in place. (1981 Code § 10.12.040)
7-3-5: TRAFFIC LANES:
   A.   The traffic engineer is authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the
roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is
necessary.
   B.   Where such traffic lanes have been marked, it shall be unlawful for the
operator of any vehicle to fail or refuse to keep such vehicle within the
boundaries of any such lane except when lawfully passing another vehicle or
preparatory to making a lawful turning movement.
   C.   Where such roadways have not been marked for traffic lanes, it shall be
unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to fail or refuse to keep such vehicle
within the boundary of any designated roadway. (1981 Code § 10.12.080)
7-3-6: CROSSWALKS:
The traffic engineer is authorized to maintain, by appropriate devices, marks
or lines, upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where,
in his opinion, there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway.
(1981 Code § 10.12.090)
7-3-7: UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS:
   A.   No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any
highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device or railroad sign or
signal, or which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official
traffic control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct
the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the
effectiveness of any official traffic control device or any railroad sign or
signal.
   B.   No person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit
upon any highway any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial
advertising.
   C.   This section shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private
property adjacent to a highway of signs giving useful directional information
and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs.
   D.   Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is declared to be a
public nuisance, and the authority having jurisdiction over the highway is
empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. (1981
Code § 10.12.060)
7-3-8: DAMAGE TO DEVICES PROHIBITED:
No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface,
injure, knock down or remove any official traffic control device, barricade or
any railroad sign or signal, or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon, or
any other part thereof. (1981 Code § 10.12.100)
CHAPTER 4
DRIVING RULES
SECTION:
7-4-1: Authorized Emergency Vehicles
7-4-2: Through And One-Way Streets; Stop And Yield Intersections
7-4-3: Speed Restrictions
7-4-4: Drive On Right
7-4-5: Driving On Roadways Laned For Traffic
7-4-6: Turning Movements
7-4-7: Overtaking And Passing Vehicles
7-4-8: Driver Signals
7-4-9: General Driving Restrictions
7-4-10: Railroad Crossings
7-4-11: Parades And Processions
7-4-12: Golf Carts And All-Terrain Vehicles
7-4-13: Careless, Negligent Driving
7-4-1: AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES:
   A.   Operation Of Vehicle On Approach Of Authorized Emergency Vehicle: Upon
the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle making use of audible
or visual signals meeting the requirements of the laws of this state, or of a
police vehicle properly and lawfully making use of an audible signal only, the
driver of every vehicle shall yield the right of way and shall immediately
drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the right hand
edge or curb of the roadway clear of any intersection, and shall stop and
remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed,
except when otherwise directed by a police officer. This subsection shall not
operate to relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty
to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the highway. (1981
Code § 10.08.090)
   B.   Fire Department Vehicles:
      1.   Following Fire Apparatus: The driver of any vehicle, other than one
on official business, shall not follow any fire apparatus traveling in response
to a fire alarm closer than five hundred feet (500') or drive into or park such
vehicle within the block where the apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire
alarm. (1981 Code § 10.08.140)
      2.   Driving Over Fire Hose: No vehicle shall be driven over any
unprotected hose of a fire department laid down on any street or private
driveway, to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the
fire department official in command. (1981 Code § 10.08.150)
7-4-2: THROUGH AND ONE-WAY STREETS; STOP AND YIELD INTERSECTIONS:
   A.   Through Streets:
      1.   Designated:
         a.   All state highway routes through the village are designated as
through streets and all conditions and regulations prescribed in other
appropriate provisions of this title shall apply to state highway routes.
         b.   Those streets and parts of streets designated by separate
ordinance and in schedule III (on file in the office of the village clerk) are
hereby declared to be through streets for the purpose of those provisions cited
in subsection A1a of this section. (1981 Code § 10.24.010)
      2.   Signs Posted: Whenever any ordinance of the village designates and
describes a through street, it shall be the duty of the village traffic
engineer to place and maintain a stop sign on each and every street
intersecting such through street unless traffic at any such intersection is
controlled at all times by traffic control signals; provided, however, that at
the intersection of two (2) such through streets or at the intersection of a
through street and a heavy traffic street not so designated, stop signs shall
be erected at the approaches of eight (8) of said streets as may be determined
by ordinances of the village from time to time. Notwithstanding the foregoing,
the village board may designate that a yield sign be placed in lieu of a stop
sign in any of the foregoing situations. (1981 Code § 10.24.020)
   B.   Stop Or Yield Intersections:
      1.   Designated: The village board may determine and designate
intersections where particular hazards exist upon other than through streets
and to determine:
         a.   Whether vehicles shall stop at one or more entrances to any such
intersection; or
         b.   Whether vehicles shall yield the right of way to vehicles on a
different street at such intersection, as prescribed in subsection B2b of this
section. (1981 Code § 10.24.030)
      2.   Procedures:
         a.   Stop Intersections:
            (1)   Except when directed to proceed by a police officer or
traffic control signal, every driver of a vehicle approaching a stop
intersection indicated by a stop sign shall stop before entering the crosswalk
on the near side of the intersection, or in the event there is no crosswalk,
then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view
of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering the
intersection.
            (2)   Such driver, after having stopped, shall yield the right of
way to any vehicle which has entered the intersection from another street or
which is approaching so closely on said street as to constitute an immediate
hazard, but said driver having so yielded may proceed, and the drivers of all
other vehicles approaching the intersection shall yield the right of way to the
vehicle so proceeding. (1981 Code § 10.24.040)
         b.   Yield Intersections:
            (1)   The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall, in
obedience to such sign, slow down to a speed reasonable for the existing
conditions, or shall stop if necessary, and shall yield the right of way to any
pedestrian legally crossing the roadway on which he is driving, and to any
vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to
constitute an immediate hazard. Said driver, having so yielded, may proceed,
and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching the intersection shall yield
to the vehicle so proceeding; provided, however, that a driver who enters a
yield intersection without stopping and has or causes a collision with a
pedestrian in a crosswalk or a vehicle in the intersection shall, prima facie,
be considered not to have yielded as required herein. The foregoing shall not
relieve the drivers of other vehicles approaching the intersection at such
distance as not to constitute an immediate hazard from the duty to drive with
due care to avoid a collision.
            (2)   The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign, if required
for safety to stop, shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side
of the intersection; or in the event there is no crosswalk, at a clearly marked
stop line; but if none, then a point nearest the intersecting roadway where the
driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. (1981
Code § 10.24.050)
   C.   One-Way Streets: Upon those streets and parts of streets and in those
alleys designated one-way, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated
direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and
maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is
prohibited. (1981 Code § 10.08.160)
7-4-3: SPEED RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Specific Speed Limits Established: It is unlawful to drive any motor
vehicle on any arterial street at a speed in excess of thirty five (35) miles
per hour and all other streets in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour, or in
an alley at a speed in excess of ten (10) miles per hour. (1981 Code §
10.16.010)
   B.   Duty To Decrease Speed: The fact that the speed of a vehicle is lower
than the limits set by this section and other provisions of this title shall
not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed when approaching and
crossing an intersection, when approaching and going around a curve, when
approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway or
when special hazards exist with respect to pedestrians or other traffic by
reason of weather or street conditions, and speed shall be decreased as may be
necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle. (1981 Code §
10.16.020)
   C.   Increased Speed Limit Permitted: It is determined upon the basis of an
engineering and traffic investigation that the speed permitted by this section
and other provisions of this title upon those streets or portions thereof
designated by ordinance and in schedule I (on file in the office of the village
clerk) is less than necessary for the safe operation of vehicles thereon by
reason of the designation and signposting of such streets as through highways,
or by reason of widely spaced intersections, and it is declared that the
maximum speed limit upon those streets or portions thereof described in
schedule I (on file in the office of the village clerk) shall be as therein
stated, which speed so declared shall be effective when signs are erected
giving notice thereof. (1981 Code § 10.16.030)
   D.   Signs Posted: The traffic engineer is authorized to regulate the timing
of traffic signals so as to permit the movement of traffic in an orderly and
safe manner at speeds slightly at variance from the speeds otherwise applicable
within a district or at intersections and shall erect appropriate signs giving
notice thereof. (1981 Code § 10.16.040)
7-4-4: DRIVE ON RIGHT:
   A.   Upon all roadways of sufficient width, a vehicle shall be driven upon
the right half of the roadway, except as follows:
      1.   When overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same
direction under the rules governing such movement.
      2.   When an obstruction exists making it necessary to drive to the left
of the center of the highway; provided, any person so doing shall yield the
right of way to all vehicles traveling in the proper direction upon the
unobstructed portion of the highway within such distance as to constitute an
immediate hazard.
      3.   Upon a roadway divided into three (3) marked lanes for traffic under
the rules applicable thereto; or
      4.   Upon a roadway designated and signposted for one-way traffic.
      5.   Whenever there is a single track paved road on one side of the
public highway and two (2) vehicles meet thereon, the driver on whose right is
the wider shoulder shall give the right of way on such pavement to the other
vehicle.
   B.   Upon all roadways, any vehicle proceeding at less than the normal speed
of traffic at the time and place and under the conditions then existing shall
be driven in the right hand lane available for traffic, or as close as
practicable to the right hand curb or edge of the roadway, except when
overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction or when
preparing for a left turn at an intersection or into a private road or
driveway. (1981 Code § 10.20.050)
7-4-5: DRIVING ON ROADWAYS LANED FOR TRAFFIC:
Whenever any roadway has been divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes
for traffic, the following rules in addition to all others consistent herewith
shall apply:
   A.   A vehicle shall be driven as nearly as practicable entirely within a
single lane and shall not be moved from such lane until the driver has first
ascertained that such movement can be made with safety.
   B.   Upon a roadway which is divided into three (3) lanes and provided for
two-way movement of traffic, a vehicle shall not be driven in the center lane
except when overtaking and passing another vehicle traveling in the same
direction when such lane is clear of traffic within a safe distance, or in
preparation for making a left turn, or where such center lane is at the time
allocated exclusively to traffic moving in the same direction that the vehicle
is proceeding and such allocation is designated by official traffic control
devices.
   C.   Official traffic control devices may be erected directing specific
traffic to use designated lanes or designating those lanes to be used by
traffic moving in a particular direction regardless of the center of the
roadway, and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of every such
device. (1981 Code § 10.20.090)
7-4-6: TURNING MOVEMENTS:
   A.   Turning At Intersections: The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at
an intersection shall do so as follows:
      1.   Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as
close as practicable to the right hand curb or edge of the roadway.
      2.   At any intersection where traffic is permitted to move in both
directions on each roadway entering the intersection, an approach for a left
turn shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the
centerline thereof and by passing to the right of such centerline where it
enters the intersection, and after entering the intersection, the left turn
shall be made so as to leave the intersection to the right of the centerline of
the roadway being entered. Whenever practicable, the left turn shall be made in
that portion of the intersection to the left of the center of the intersection.
      3.   At any intersection where traffic is restricted to one direction on
one or more of the roadways, the driver of a vehicle intending to turn left at
any such intersection shall approach the intersection in the extreme left hand
lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the direction of travel of such
vehicle, and after entering the intersection, the left turn shall be made so as
to leave the intersection, as nearly as practicable, in the left hand lane
lawfully available to traffic moving in such direction upon the roadway being
entered. (1981 Code § 10.20.010)
   B.   Intersection Turn Lanes: Where traffic lanes have been marked upon the
street for "left turn only" or "right turn only" in correlation with an
intersection where a traffic control signal is installed and operated, drivers
of vehicles shall use such lanes only for the left turn or right turn, as the
case may be, and it is unlawful for any driver approaching such intersection to
drive in said lane unless he shall be intending to make a left turn or right
turn, as the case may be, in compliance with the proper signal displayed to him
by the traffic control signal. (1981 Code § 10.20.110)
   C.   Prohibited Left Turns: It is unlawful for any person to make a left
turn in any of the areas designated by ordinance and schedule II (on file in
the office of the village clerk) when signs are erected giving notice thereof.
(1981 Code § 10.20.030)
   D.   Turning To Proceed In Opposite Direction: The driver of any vehicle
shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any
street in the village. (1981 Code § 10.20.040)
   E.   Signs And Signals:
      1.   Placement: The traffic engineer is authorized to place markers,
buttons or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to
be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections.
      2.   Obedience Required: When authorized markers, buttons or other
indicators are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be
traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the
directions of such indicators. (1981 Code § 10.20.020)
7-4-7: OVERTAKING AND PASSING VEHICLES:
   A.   Generally: The following rules shall govern the overtaking and passing
of vehicles proceeding in the same direction, subject to those limitations,
exceptions, and special rules hereinafter stated:
      1.   The driver of a vehicle overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the
same direction shall pass to the left thereof at a safe distance and shall not
again drive to the right side of the roadway until safely clear of the
overtaken vehicle.
      2.   Except when overtaking and passing on the right is permitted, the
driver of an overtaken vehicle shall give way to the right in favor of the
overtaking vehicle on audible signal and shall not increase the speed of his
vehicle until completely passed by the overtaking vehicle. (1981 Code §
10.20.060)
   B.   Overtaking Vehicles On Right:
      1.   The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass upon the right of
another vehicle only under the following conditions:
         a.   When the vehicle overtaken is making or about to make a left
turn. (1981 Code § 10.20.070)
         b.   Upon a street or highway with unobstructed pavement or roadway
with sufficient width for two (2) or more lines of moving vehicles in each
direction. (1981 Code § 10.20.070; amd. 2012 Code)
         c.   Upon a one-way street or upon any roadway on which traffic is
restricted to one direction of movement, where the roadway is free from
obstructions and of sufficient width for two (2) or more lines of moving
vehicles.
      2.   The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass another vehicle upon
the right only under conditions permitting such movement in safety. In no event
shall such movement be made by driving off the pavement or main traveled
portion of the roadway. (1981 Code § 10.20.070)
   C.   Overtaking Vehicles On Left:
      1.   No vehicle shall be driven to the left side of the center of the
roadway in overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same
direction unless such left side is clearly visible and is free of oncoming
traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit such overtaking and passing
to be completely made without interfering with the safe operation of any
vehicle approaching from the opposite direction or any vehicle overtaken. In
every event, the overtaking vehicle must return to the right hand side of the
roadway before coming within two hundred feet (200') of any vehicle approaching
from the opposite direction.
      2.   a. No vehicle shall, in overtaking and passing another vehicle or at
any other time, be driven to the left side of the roadway under the following
conditions:
            (1)   When approaching the crest of a grade or upon a curve in the
highway where the driver's view is obstructed within such distances as to
create a hazard in the event another vehicle might approach from the opposite
direction.
            (2)   When approaching within one hundred feet (100') of or
crossing an intersection or railroad grade crossing.
            (3)   Where official signs are in place directing that traffic keep
to the right or a distinctive centerline is marked, which distinctive line also
directs traffic.
         b.   The limitations in subsections C2a(1) and C2a(2) of this section
shall not apply upon a one-way roadway or upon a roadway with unobstructed
pavement of sufficient width for two (2) or more lanes of moving traffic in
each direction when such movement can be made with safety. (1981 Code §
10.20.080)
7-4-8: DRIVER SIGNALS:
It is unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to start, slow down, stop or
attempt to turn such vehicle without first giving a suitable signal in the
manner required by Illinois Compiled Statutes for such circumstances. (1981
Code § 10.20.120; amd. 2012 Code)
7-4-9: GENERAL DRIVING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Following Too Closely: The driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow
another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard
for the speed of such vehicles and the traffic upon and the condition of the
highway. (1981 Code § 10.20.100)
   B.   Driving On Sidewalks: The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within
any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. (1981 Code §
10.20.140)
   C.   Emerging From Alley, Driveway Or Building: The driver of a vehicle
emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop such vehicle
immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk area extending across any alleyway
or driveway, and shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian as may be
necessary to avoid collision, and upon entering the roadway, shall yield the
right of way to all vehicles approaching on said roadway. (1981 Code §
10.24.060)
   D.   Blocking Intersections: No driver shall enter an intersection or a
marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the
intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without
obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any
traffic control signal indication to proceed. (1981 Code § 10.24.070)
   E.   Backing Restrictions: The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same
unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering
with other traffic. (1981 Code § 10.08.130)
   F.   Opening Vehicle Door: No person shall open the door of a motor vehicle
on the side available to moving traffic unless and until it is reasonably safe
to do so, nor shall any person leave a door open on the side of a motor vehicle
available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load
or unload passengers. (1981 Code § 10.20.130)
7-4-10: RAILROAD CROSSINGS:
   A.   Whenever any person driving a vehicle approaches a railroad grade
crossing under any of the circumstances stated in this section, the driver of
such vehicle shall stop within fifty feet (50') but not less than ten feet
(10') from the nearest rail of such railroad, and shall not proceed until he
can do so safely. The foregoing requirements shall apply when:
      1.   A clearly visible electric or mechanical signal device gives warning
of the immediate approach of a railroad train.
      2.   A crossing gate is lowered or a flagman gives or continues to give a
signal of the approach or passage of a railroad train.
      3.   An approaching train is plainly visible and is in hazardous
proximity to such crossing.
   B.   No person shall drive any vehicle through, around or under any crossing
gate or barrier at a railroad crossing while such gate or barrier is closed or
is being opened or closed. (1981 Code § 10.24.080)
7-4-11: PARADES AND PROCESSIONS:
   A.   Permit And Compliance Required: No procession or parade containing
fifty (50) or more persons or fifteen (15) or more vehicles, except the forces
of the United States army or navy, the military forces of this state and the
forces of the police and fire departments, shall occupy, march or proceed along
any street except in accordance with a permit issued by the chief of police and
in compliance with such traffic regulations as are set forth herein which may
apply. (1981 Code § 10.32.010)
   B.   Identification Required: A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles
shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of
a pennant or other identifying insignia. All vehicles in a procession shall at
all times have their headlights turned on. (1981 Code § 10.32.020)
   C.   Drivers In A Procession: Each driver in a funeral or other procession
shall drive as near to the right hand edge of the roadway as practicable and
shall follow the car ahead as close as is practicable and safe. Notwithstanding
the foregoing, each driver shall at all times have the duty to drive with due
regard for the safety of all persons using the streets, and this subsection
does not protect the driver of any such vehicle described herein from the
consequences of reckless disregard for the safety of others. (1981 Code §
10.32.030)
   D.   Driving Through Processions: No driver of a vehicle shall drive between
the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are
in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in
this section. (1981 Code § 10.32.040)
7-4-12: GOLF CARTS AND ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
    ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLE OR UTILITY TERRAIN VEHICLE: A self-propelled, four (4)
wheeled motor vehicle which is capable of attaining, within one mile, a speed
of more than ten (10) miles per hour but not more than twenty five (25) miles
per hour.
   GOLF CART: A vehicle specifically designed and intended for the purpose of
transporting one or more persons and their golf clubs or maintenance equipment.
   B.   Use On Public Ways Prohibited; Exceptions: The use or operation of a
golf cart, all-terrain vehicle, or utility terrain vehicle on any public
street, sidewalk, or alley within the village is hereby prohibited unless said
use is by an employee or authorized agent of a unit of local government, school
district, or state or federal government in the performance of their official
duties. (Ord. 918, 6-6-2011)
7-4-13: CARELESS, NEGLIGENT DRIVING:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle in the village in a careless,
negligent or wanton manner, so as to endanger life or property. (1981 Code §
10.28.020)
CHAPTER 5
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
7-5-1: Method Of Parking
7-5-2: Unattended Vehicle
7-5-3: General Parking Restrictions
7-5-4: Specific No Parking Places; Moving Parked Vehicle
7-5-5: Additional Parking Restrictions; Time Limit Parking
7-5-6: Residential Parking On Certain Streets (Rep. by Ord. 953, 8-19-2013)
7-5-7: Village Parking Lots
7-5-1: METHOD OF PARKING:
   A.   Parallel Parking:
      1.   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter and other appropriate
provisions of this title, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway where
there are adjacent curbs shall be so stopped or parked with the right hand
wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within twelve inches (12") of the right
hand curb in accordance with state law. (1981 Code § 10.52.010; amd. 2012 Code)
      2.   Except where parking has been prohibited or where the village board,
by ordinance, has provided that angle parking shall be permitted, no person
shall park or stand a vehicle other than parallel to the curb or edge of the
roadway. (1981 Code § 10.52.020)
   B.   Angle Parking: On those streets which have been signed or marked by the
traffic engineer for angle parking, according to village ordinances, no person
shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of
the roadway indicated by such signs or markings. (1981 Code § 10.52.030)
7-5-2: UNATTENDED VEHICLE:
No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand
unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition and removing
the key; or when standing upon any perceptible grade, without effectively
setting the brake thereon and turning the front wheels to the curb or side of
the street. (1981 Code § 10.44.040)
7-5-3: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Obstructing Traffic Or Driveway Entrance: No person shall park any
vehicle upon a street or alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to
leave available less than ten feet (10') of the width of the roadway for free
movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a
vehicle in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting
property.
   B.   Parking For Certain Purposes Prohibited: No person shall park a vehicle
upon any roadway for the principal purpose of:
      1.   Displaying such vehicle for sale.
      2.   Greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by an
emergency.
   C.   Narrow Streets: When official signs prohibiting parking are erected
upon narrow streets as authorized by law, no person shall park a vehicle upon
any such street in violation thereof.
   D.   Hazardous Or Congested Places:
      1.   The village board, by ordinance, may designate places in which the
stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous
condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic.
      2.   When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as
authorized herein, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such
designated place.
   E.   Schools:
      1.   The village board may, by ordinance, provide no parking upon either
or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking
would, in the board's opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous
situation.
      2.   When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon either
side of a street adjacent to any school property, as authorized herein, no
person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place.
   F.   For purposes of this section only, a "side yard" is defined as a space
extending from the front yard to the rear yard between the principal building
and the side lot line, measured perpendicular from the side lot line to the
closest point of the principal building.
   G.   All vehicles in any SR-1 or MR-1 district parked in a front or side
yard shall be on an improved surface. Any vehicles which are subject to
Illinois Secretary of State licensure shall have a current Illinois
registration with the Illinois Secretary of State's Office.
   H.   An "improved surface" as used herein is defined as a continuous surface
construction of concrete, blacktop, or paving stone, which is complete and
uninterrupted underneath all portions of the vehicle being placed on the
surface.
   I.   Drainage easements shall not be encroached upon by such improved
surfaces or vehicles. (1981 Code §§ 10.52.050 through 10.52.090; amd. Ord.
1107A, 10-16-2023)
7-5-4: SPECIFIC NO PARKING PLACES; MOVING PARKED VEHICLE:
   A.   Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in
compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic
control device, no person shall:
      1.   Stop, stand or park a vehicle:
         a.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge
or curb of a street.
         b.   On a sidewalk.
         c.   Within an intersection.
         d.   On a crosswalk.
         e.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone,
unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings.
         f.   On a grassed, seeded or sodded strip between the roadway and the
sidewalk or property line.
         g.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
         h.   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or
within a highway tunnel.
         i.   On any railroad tracks. A violation of any part of this
subsection A1i shall result in a mandatory fine of five hundred dollars
($500.00) or fifty (50) hours of community service.
         j.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping.
         k.   On any controlled access highway.
         l.   In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including
crossovers.
         m.   In a public parking area if the vehicle does not display a
current annual registration sticker or current temporary permit pending
registration.
      2.   Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily
to pick up or discharge passengers:
         a.   In front of a public or private driveway.
         b.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
         c.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
         d.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing
signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of
a roadway.
         e.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly signposted).
         f.   At any place where official signs prohibit standing.
      3.   Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the
purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or
passengers:
         a.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad
crossing.
         b.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
   B.   No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any
such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. (1981
Code § 10.52.040; amd. 2012 Code)
7-5-5: ADDITIONAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS; TIME LIMIT PARKING:
   A.   Application Of Provisions: The provisions of this section prohibiting
the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times
herein specified or as indicated on official signs except when it is necessary
to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with
the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. (1981
Code § 10.52.110)
   B.   Regulations Not Exclusive: The provisions of this section imposing a
time limit to parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe
other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping,
standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times.
(1981 Code § 10.52.120)
   C.   Parking Prohibited At All Times: When signs are erected giving notice
thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets
described. (1981 Code § 10.52.130)
   D.   Parking Times Limited; Days Restricted:
      1.   When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no
person shall park a vehicle between the hours specified on that day. (1981 Code
§ 10.52.140)
      2.   When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no
person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle between the hours specified on any
day, except Sundays and public holidays, upon any of the streets described.
(1981 Code § 10.52.150)
      3.   When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no
person shall park a vehicle for longer than the times designated on any day,
except Sundays and public holidays, upon any of the streets described. (1981
Code § 10.52.160)
   E.   Parking Longer Than Three Days: Any vehicle that remains parked upon
any public street or alley shall, after three (3) days, be deemed abandoned,
and shall, at the direction of the village police, be towed away and stored at
the expense of the owner of such vehicle. (1981 Code § 10.52.190; amd. 2012
Code)
   F.   Signs Posted: Whenever, by this chapter or any other ordinance of the
village, any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on
designated streets, it shall be the duty of the traffic engineer to erect
appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be
effective unless the signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged
offense. (1981 Code § 10.52.170)
7-5-6: RESIDENTIAL PARKING ON CERTAIN STREETS:
(Rep. by Ord. 953, 8-19-2013)
7-5-7: VILLAGE PARKING LOTS:
   A.   Regulations:
      1.   The village board of trustees is authorized to regulate the use of
parking lots owned or controlled by the village. The regulations may include:
a) the designation of parking places for particular purposes, e.g., for the
disabled, fire department use, police department use, or other specified use;
b) restrictions on the period of time for which parking is permitted; or c)
other purposes as permitted by law.
      2.   These regulations shall be adopted by resolution adopted from time
to time by the board of trustees, as reflected either by written resolution or
clearly set forth in the minutes of the proceedings.
   B.   Signs Posted: Signs shall be posted designating the regulations,
prohibitions or restrictions, as applicable.
   C.   Permits May Be Issued: Permits may be issued, if appropriate.
   D.   Violations; Penalties:
      1.   It is unlawful for any person to violate such regulations,
prohibitions or restrictions.
      2.   Violation of parking reserved for the disabled shall be punished by
the laws of the state of Illinois or the ordinances of the village.
      3.   Other violations shall be subject to the penalties set forth in
chapter 2 of this title.
      4.   In addition to any other remedy, if the vehicle represents a safety
threat or if the owner or operator cannot be reasonably notified to correct the
violation, then an offending vehicle may be towed at the expense of the owner
or operator. (Ord. 704, 9-3-1997)
CHAPTER 6
PEDESTRIANS
SECTION:
7-6-1: Application Of Regulations
7-6-2: Crosswalks
7-6-3: Crossing At Other Than Crosswalks
7-6-4: Walking Along Roadways
7-6-5: Hitchhiking Prohibited
7-6-6: Pedestrians With Disabilities
7-6-7: Drivers To Exercise Due Care
7-6-8: Penalty
7-6-1: APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS:
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control signals. (1981 Code §
10.64.010; amd. 2012 Code)
7-6-2: CROSSWALKS:
   A.   Right Of Way:
      1.   When traffic control signals are not in place or not in operation,
the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way, slowing down or stopping
if need be to so yield to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk.
      2.   Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any
unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the
roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not
overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. (1981 Code § 10.64.020)
   B.   Use Of Crosswalks:
      1.   Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are
in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except a crosswalk.
(1981 Code § 10.64.060)
      2.   No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curbing or other place of
safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is
impossible for the driver to yield. (1981 Code § 10.64.020)
      3.   Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of
crosswalks. (1981 Code § 10.64.030)
      4.   Pedestrians in marked or unmarked crosswalks shall proceed across
the roadway with dispatch when the way is clear. It is unlawful for pedestrians
to delay vehicular traffic which has yielded to pedestrians by deliberately
straggling, stalling or in any other way deliberately hindering such vehicles.
(1981 Code § 10.64.040)
7-6-3: CROSSING AT OTHER THAN CROSSWALKS:
Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked
crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at any intersection shall yield the
right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway. (1981 Code § 10.64.050)
7-6-4: WALKING ALONG ROADWAYS:
   A.   Where sidewalks are provided, it is unlawful for any pedestrian to walk
along and upon an adjacent roadway.
   B.   Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon
a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the roadway or
its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction.
(1981 Code § 10.64.070)
7-6-5: HITCHHIKING PROHIBITED:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to stand or loiter upon any sidewalk,
street, avenue, alley or public highway or grounds within the limits of the
village for the purpose of "thumbing", requesting, asking or soliciting a ride
from the operator of any motor vehicle.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person, within the village to engage in what is
known as "hitchhiking". (1981 Code § 10.64.090)
7-6-6: PEDESTRIANS WITH DISABILITIES:
The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian with
clearly visible disabilities. (1981 Code § 10.64.080; amd. 2012 Code)
7-6-7: DRIVERS TO EXERCISE DUE CARE:
Notwithstanding the provisions of this title, every driver of a vehicle shall
exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and
shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise
proper precaution upon any child or confused or incapacitated person upon a
roadway. (1981 Code § 10.64.100)
7-6-8: PENALTY:
Every person convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be punishable as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1981 Code § 10.64.110; amd. 2012 Code)
CHAPTER 7
BICYCLES
SECTION:
7-7-1: Traffic Laws Apply
7-7-2: Obedience To Traffic Control Devices
7-7-3: Operation Of Bicycles
7-7-4: Equipment Requirements
7-7-5: Penalty
7-7-1: TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY:
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights
and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle
by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles,
or by the traffic ordinances of the village applicable to the driver of a
vehicle, except as to special regulations in this chapter and chapter 2,
article A of this title, and except as to those provisions of laws and
ordinances which, by their nature, can have no application. (1981 Code §
10.60.010)
7-7-2: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
   A.   Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official
traffic control signals and signs and other control devices applicable to
vehicles unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
   B.   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left
or U-turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the
direction of any sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to
make any such turn, in which event, such person shall then obey the regulations
applicable to pedestrians. (1981 Code § 10.60.020)
7-7-3: OPERATION OF BICYCLES:
   A.   Riding On Bicycles:
      1.   A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a
permanent and regular seat attached thereto.
      2.   No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the
number for which it is designed and equipped. (1981 Code § 10.60.030)
   B.   Riding On Roadways And Bicycle Paths:
      1.   Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near
to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when
passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction.
      2.   Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two
(2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive
use of bicycles.
      3.   Wherever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a
roadway, bicycle riders shall use such paths and shall not use the roadway.
(1981 Code § 10.60.040)
   C.   Speed Restriction: No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater
than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. (1981 Code §
10.60.050)
   D.   Entering Public Ways: The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley,
driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area
extending across any alleyway, yield the right of way to all pedestrians
approaching on such sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway, shall yield
the right of way to all vehicles approaching on said roadway. (1981 Code §
10.60.060)
   E.   Riding On Sidewalks: Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a
sidewalk, such person shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian and shall
give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. (1981 Code §
10.60.090)
   F.   Carrying Articles: No person operating a bicycle shall carry any
package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one
hand upon the handlebars. (1981 Code § 10.60.070)
   G.   Parking: No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon
the roadway against the curb, or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the
bicycle, or against a building, or at the curb in such a manner as to afford
the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. (1981 Code § 10.60.080)
7-7-4: EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Lamps And Reflector: Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be
equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a
distance of at least five hundred feet (500') to the front and with a red
reflector on the rear of a type which shall be visible from all distances from
fifty feet (50') to three hundred feet (300') to the rear when directly in
front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a
red light visible from a distance of five hundred feet (500') to the rear may
be used in addition to the red reflector.
   B.   Signal Device: No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped
with a device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least one
hundred feet (100'); except, that a bicycle shall not be equipped with nor
shall any person use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle.
   C.   Brake: Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable
the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. (1981
Code § 10.60.100)
7-7-5: PENALTY:
Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter and
chapter 2, article A of this title shall be punishable as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1981 Code § 10.60.110; amd. 2012 Code)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
SECTION:
8-1-1: Permit To Construct Or Repair
8-1-2: Construction Specifications
8-1-3: Repairs And Defects
8-1-4: Safety Precautions
8-1-5: Openings In Public Ways
8-1-6: Deposits On Streets And Sidewalks
8-1-7: Utility Poles And Wires
8-1-8: Commercial Activities On Village Property
8-1-9: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
8-1-10: Penalty
8-1-1: PERMIT TO CONSTRUCT OR REPAIR:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to construct or lay any pavement
on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, or to repair the
same, without having first received approval by the village.
   B.   Application For Permit: Applications for such permits shall be to the
clerk and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the
extent thereof, and the person or firm who is to do the actual construction
work. No such permits shall be issued except where the work will conform to the
ordinances of the village.
   C.   Bond: Each applicant shall file a bond in an amount set by the public
works director with surety to be approved by the public works director
conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss or damage resulting from the
work undertaken or the manner of doing the same. (2012 Code)
8-1-2: CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS:
All street and sidewalk pavements shall be made in conformity with
specifications laid down or approved from time to time by the village board of
trustees. (2012 Code)
8-1-3: REPAIRS AND DEFECTS:
   A.   Repairs Required: All public street, alley, and sidewalk pavements
shall be in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the village or by
the abutting owner, shall be under the supervision of the director of public
works.
   B.   Defects Reported: It shall be the duty of every village officer and
employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk, or
any obstruction thereof, to report the same to the director of public works as
soon as possible. (2012 Code)
8-1-4: SAFETY PRECAUTIONS:
   A.   Safety Precautions Required:
      1.   Construction And Repair Work: Any person, firm or corporation laying
or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place or making
an excavation in the same, shall maintain suitable barriers and warning devices
to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the work.
      2.   Barriers And Warning Devices: Any defect in any such pavement shall
be protected with barriers and warning devices to prevent injury; and any
person, firm or corporation properly maintaining any opening or excavation,
while the same remains open, shall guard the same with proper barriers and
warning devices.
   B.   Disturbing Safety Devices Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to disturb
or interfere with any barriers and warning devices lawfully placed to protect
or mark any new pavement or excavation or opening in any public street, alley
or sidewalk. (2012 Code)
8-1-5: OPENINGS IN PUBLIC WAYS:
It shall be unlawful to construct any opening or stairway in any public street
or sidewalk or alley without approval from the public works director. All such
lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover or
railing to the approval of the public works director. (2012 Code)
8-1-6: DEPOSITS ON STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Deposits On Streets: It shall be unlawful to deposit on any street any
material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof or which may impede any
public right of way drainage area, or any waste material, or any glass or other
articles which may do injury to any person, animal or property.
   B.   Deposits On Sidewalks:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk any material
which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any
glass or other articles which might cause injury to persons, animals or
property.
      2.   Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks
preparatory to delivery; provided, that the usable width of the sidewalk is not
thereby reduced to less than four feet (4'); and provided, that no such article
shall remain on such walk for more than a normal working day. (2012 Code)
8-1-7: UTILITY POLES AND WIRES:
It shall be unlawful to erect any poles or wires or maintain any poles or wires
over any public place, street, alley or other public way without having first
secured permission from the public works director. (2012 Code)
8-1-8: COMMERCIAL ACTIVITIES ON VILLAGE PROPERTY:
On all property owned by the village, including the parking lots maintained and
owned by the village, all commercial activities by private citizens shall be
prohibited and not allowed thereon, and all parking shall not extend for more
than three (3) days without written permission from the public works director.
Upon a violation of this section by engaging in any commercial activity
thereon, or by parking for a longer period than that prescribed herein, the
same is declared to be a violation of this section, and the person guilty of
said violation shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 486, 7-15-
1985; amd. 2012 Code)
8-1-9: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Injuring New Pavements: It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any
vehicle or animal upon, or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement
while the same is guarded by barriers and warning devices or to knowingly
injure any soft or newly laid pavement.
   B.   Private Use; Graffiti: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to use any street, sidewalk or other public place as space for the
display of goods or merchandise for sale, or to write or make any sign or
advertisement on any such pavement.
   C.   Playing Games: It shall be unlawful to play any games upon any street,
alley, or sidewalk or other public property, where such games cause unnecessary
noise or interfere with traffic or pedestrians. (2012 Code)
8-1-10: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be punishable as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (2012
Code)
CHAPTER 2
WATER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:
8-2-1: Metered Water Required
8-2-2: Contract For Water Service
8-2-3: Service Connections
8-2-4: Rates And Charges
8-2-5: Groundwater As Potable Water Prohibited; Exception
8-2-1: METERED WATER REQUIRED:
All water to be furnished to the citizens of the village through what is
commonly known as the Roxana water system shall be supplied through approved
water meters to be furnished by the village, and not at any time by what is
designated as a flat rate. (1981 Code § 13.04.010)
8-2-2: CONTRACT FOR WATER SERVICE:
All contracts for the installation of meters and the furnishing of water must
be entered into by either the owner or the tenant of the property desired to be
served and the village. In no case shall any water services be installed until
such contract is made and entered into. As used in this section, the word
"contract" shall mean establishing a water account via a deposit fee. (1981
Code § 13.04.020; amd. 2012 Code)
8-2-3: SERVICE CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Installation And Approval: Each tap into the water lines shall be
subject to the approval of the water department. The village shall present the
mode of tapping, the form, and the materials for all connections to be made
with the water lines. The village shall supervise, perform, or select a
contractor to make taps and service connections. All costs for the labor and
materials for taps and service connections shall be paid to the water
department prior to water being supplied to the service. The expense of
installing, maintaining, repairing and replacing an existing or a new water
line from the property line to the point of service shall be the responsibility
of the property owner. (Ord. 835, 3-20-2006)
   B.   Connection Fees:
      1.   Residential Service:
         a.   For each new residential service connection within the corporate
limits of the village, there shall be a nonrefundable tap-on or connection fee
of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a connection up to one
inch (1") in diameter.
         b.   For each new multi-family residential service within the
corporate limits of the village, the fee in subsection B1a of this section
shall apply. Condominium units shall be deemed to be individual residential
units.
      2.   Service Outside Village Limits: For any water service connection
made to the village water distribution system to provide water service to a
location outside of the corporate limits of the village, the tap-on fee shall
be the sum of two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00) for a one inch (1")
connection, and an additional cost of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per one-
fourth inch (1/4") size of the connection larger than one inch (1") in
diameter. Village labor and material costs to install such connection will
apply in addition to the tap-on connection fee. (Ord. 851, 6-18-2007)
8-2-4: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Definition: For the purpose of this section, the term "quarter" shall
mean three (3) months of any one year, and said quarters shall commence on
December 1, March 1, June 1 and September 1 of each year.
   B.   Conditions Of Establishing An Account:
      1.   Prior to any person obtaining water service from the village, such
person must comply with the following for each account:
         a.   Comply with title 9, chapter 6 of this code, provisions which
govern residential occupancy requirements.
         b.   Pay a nonrefundable service fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) to
establish the account. This amount will then be deposited in the water
operation and maintenance fund.
         c.   Pay a deposit fee of sixty five dollars ($65.00). Interest shall
not be calculated nor applied to any amount of the deposit refund when the
account is closed.
         d.   Pay any tap-on or connecting fee, if applicable.
         e.   All fees for water service shall be made payable to the Roxana
water department.
      2.   Any funds held as the deposit shall be applied toward any
outstanding balance on the account. The remaining portion of the deposit shall
be refunded to the user upon termination of service for that account.
   C.   Classes Of Users; Rates Established: Effective June 1, 2006, the
following rates shall apply to those persons who use, purchase or order water
from the village:
      1.   Class I, residential units within the village limits (including
churches): Minimum of sixteen dollars fifty cents ($16.50) per residential unit
per quarter for the first three thousand (3,000) gallons and two dollars forty
four cents ($2.44) per user per quarter for each one thousand (1,000) gallons
or portion thereof in excess of the first three thousand (3,000) gallons.
      2.   Class II, residential and commercial units located outside the
corporate limits of the village: Minimum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per
residential user per quarter and two dollars seventy five cents ($2.75) for
each one thousand (1,000) gallons or portion thereof in excess of the first
five thousand (5,000) gallons per user per quarter.
      3.   Class III, commercial and light industrial: Two dollars thirteen
cents ($2.13) per each one thousand (1,000) gallons or fraction thereof per
user per month. This shall not impair nor prohibit existing rates or rates
which have been or may be established pursuant to meeting the individual needs
of certain users, which may include current or future water users.
      4.   Class IV, large heavy industrial: One dollar sixty cents ($1.60) per
each one thousand (1,000) gallons or portion thereof per user per month.
      5.   Class V, any water sold in bulk by direct connection such as from a
hydrant meter or fire hose: Minimum of twenty dollars ($20.00) and two dollars
fifty cents ($2.50) per one thousand (1,000) gallons.
      6.   Class VI, village of South Roxana, Illinois, and village of
Hartford, Illinois: Two dollars twenty eight cents ($2.28) per each one
thousand (1,000) gallons or portion thereof per month. Notwithstanding the
above, this rate shall become effective May 1, 2006.
      7.   Class VII, significant industrial user fees: The Village shall
negotiate with significant industrial users individually for fee amounts and
the fees associated with water usage and services shall be laid out in the
contract between the significant industrial user and the Village.
   D.   Meter Readings: The rates charged all users shall be based upon the
meter readings taken at the end of each quarter for class I and any other users
that shall be billed quarterly, and the beginning of each month for users that
are billed or have requested monthly billing cycles. A bill, with its date
indicated, shall be sent to the user for each monthly or quarterly period, as
applicable.
   E.   Rendition Of Bills And Collection Of Payments: It is hereby made the
duty of the water department to render bills for water service and all other
charges in connection therewith and to collect all monies due thereon. It shall
also be the duty of the water department to attempt collection of any and all
delinquencies.
   F.   Payments And Delinquencies: The following shall apply for the payment
of water service:
      1.   Due Date: All accounts shall be paid in full within twenty (20) days
of the date of the bill. No discounts shall be allowed.
      2.   Late Payment Penalty: Accounts remaining unpaid after twenty (20)
days of the date of the bill shall be assessed a penalty of fifteen percent
(15%) of the outstanding balance, which amount shall be added to such
outstanding balance.
      3.   Notice Of Delinquency; Use Of Deposit; Responsibility For Other
Costs: Accounts remaining unpaid thirty (30) days after the date of the bill
are declared to be delinquent. The village water department shall notify each
user whose bill is delinquent that unless such delinquent user pays the full
amount of his outstanding balance on or before the date which is forty (40)
days after the date of the bill, that water service to such user shall be shut
off and disconnected. It shall be sufficient for this delinquent notice to be
sent by first class prepaid postage via the United States postal service. No
further notice shall be required prior to the water service being shut off or
disconnected. The water deposit on the account shall be applied to any unpaid
balance remaining, and any additional monies owed shall be billed as final
usage on the account. In addition, any delinquent party shall pay to the
village any and all attorney fees, court costs and litigation expenses incurred
necessary to enforce this section or to collect such amounts.
      4.   Disconnection Of Service; Fee: Water service shall be shut off and
disconnected for each account where the outstanding balance has not been paid
in full on or before forty (40) days after the date of the bill. The waterworks
superintendent is hereby directed, authorized, instructed and ordered to shut
off and disconnect such water service. A nonrefundable disconnect fee of thirty
dollars ($30.00) shall be added to the outstanding balance of the account for
each such user whose service is disconnected.
      5.   Final Meter Reading Or Estimate: The waterworks superintendent shall
make a final meter reading upon shutting off or disconnecting water service. In
the event that the meter is not available for inspection upon the water service
being shut off or disconnected, the waterworks superintendent shall estimate
the water usage, with five percent (5%) being added to that estimate. A final
calculation shall be made of the user's water bill, and such amount shall be
added to the outstanding balance of the account. The use of an estimated water
bill for this purpose shall not alter the user's liability if a subsequent
meter reading determines a higher liability.
      6.   Restoration Of Service: Users whose water service has been shut off
or disconnected may have water service restored within five (5) days of such
shutoff or disconnection by paying in full their outstanding balance and any
associated fees with reestablishing the service.
      7.   Account Closed: Should there remain an outstanding balance of an
account for more than five (5) days following water service being shut off or
disconnected, such account shall be considered closed. The deposit for such
account shall be applied toward payment of the outstanding balance. Should the
amount of the deposit exceed the outstanding balance, a refund will be
forwarded to the user at his last known address. Should the outstanding balance
exceed the amount of the deposit, a statement shall be sent to the user at his
last known address for the amount due.
   G.   Interpretation Of Provisions:
      1.   This section shall not abolish or extinguish any right, duty or
obligation which may exist on the effective date hereof. In the event this
section conflicts with any previous ordinance of the village regarding the
subject matter hereof, then this section shall be controlling.
      2.   The rates, fees, deposits and penalties set forth herein are
cumulative to any other rates, fees, deposits or penalties which are otherwise
provided by law. (Ord. 835, 3-20-2006; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 1097, - -2023)
8-2-5: GROUNDWATER AS POTABLE WATER PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION:
   A.   Definitions:
    PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation association, joint stock company, trust, estate,
political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or its legal representatives,
agents or assigns.
   POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption including,
but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes,
or preparing foods.
   B.   Use Prohibited; Exception: Except for such uses or methods in existence
before the effective date hereof, the use or attempt to use as a potable water
supply groundwater from within the boundaries of the corporate limits of the
village as identified on exhibit A attached to the ordinance codified herein as
a potable water supply by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other
method is hereby prohibited. This prohibition expressly includes the village.
(Ord. 867, 6-2-2008)
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be
subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each violation. (Ord. 867, 6-2-2008; amd. 2012 Code)
ARTICLE A. CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
SECTION:
8-2A-1: Cross Connections Restricted
8-2A-2: Surveys And Investigations
8-2A-3: Backflow Prevention Device
8-2A-4: Entry Powers; Inspections
8-2A-5: Violations; Disconnection Of Water Service; Reconnect Fee
8-2A-6: Responsibility For Cleanup Costs
8-2A-1: CROSS CONNECTIONS RESTRICTED:
No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or
maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary
or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the
village may enter the supply or distribution system thereof, unless such
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and
use of such supply shall have been approved by the superintendent of water and
complies with the Illinois environment protection agency regulations. (Ord.
493, 3-24-1986; amd. 2012 Code)
8-2A-2: SURVEYS AND INVESTIGATIONS:
It shall be the duty of the superintendent of water to cause surveys and
investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served by the
public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the
public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a
matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two (2) years, or
as often as the superintendent of water shall deem necessary. Records of such
surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least
five (5) years. (Ord. 493, 3-24-1986)
8-2A-3: BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE:
If, in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code or in the judgment of the
superintendent of water, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary
for the safety of the public water supply system, the superintendent of water
will give notice to the water customer to install such an approved device
immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an
approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois
plumbing code and all applicable local regulations, and shall have inspections
and tests made of such approved device as required by the Illinois plumbing
code and local regulations. The installation thereof, being of such complex
nature, shall be made by a licensed plumber, licensed under the Illinois
requirements therefor, who has additionally been certified by the Illinois
environmental protection agency as qualified as a cross connection control
inspector. (Ord. 493, 3-24-1986)
8-2A-4: ENTRY POWERS; INSPECTIONS:
   A.   The approved cross connection control device inspector shall have the
right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to
the public water supply or distribution system of the village water department
for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross connections, and
the water superintendent or his authorized agent shall have the right to enter
at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water
supply or distribution system of the village water department for the purpose
of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross
connection control inspection. On demand, the owner, lessees or occupants of
any property so served shall furnish to the superintendent of water any
information which he may request regarding the piping system or systems or
water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when demanded,
shall, within the discretion of the superintendent of water, be deemed evidence
of the presence of improper connections as provided in this article.
   B.   The device shall be inspected annually. The inspection shall include
physical testing in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Customers
shall notify the water department by mail no later than ten (10) days after the
inspection. The notification shall include the date of the inspection, the firm
that conducted the inspection, along with the firm's license number, and the
inspector's cross connection control certification identification number. The
results and recommendations of the inspection shall also be included in the
notification. The customer who possesses the device shall maintain detailed
records for examination by the water superintendent or his authorized agent.
Included in those records will be the manufacturer's instructions and records
regarding installation, inspection, testing, repairs and alterations. Failure
to conduct inspections or to notify the water department of said inspections
shall be deemed as negligent on the customer's part, and disconnection of the
customer's service will take place on the water superintendent's order. (Ord.
493, 3-24-1986)
8-2A-5: VIOLATIONS; DISCONNECTION OF WATER SERVICE; RECONNECT FEE:
The village superintendent of water is hereby authorized and directed to
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service
to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this
article is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he
may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water
supply distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored
until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the
provisions of this article, and until a reconnection fee of one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00) is paid to the village. Immediate disconnection with verbal
notice can be effected when the superintendent of water is assured that
imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public water supply system
exists. Such action shall be followed by written notification of the cause of
disconnection. (Ord. 493, 3-24-1986)
8-2A-6: RESPONSIBILITY FOR CLEANUP COSTS:
The consumer responsible for back siphoned material or contamination through
backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an
illegal cross connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired
device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear the cost of cleanup of
the potable water supply system. (Ord. 493, 3-24-1986)
CHAPTER 3
SEWER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:
8-3-1: Connection To Public System Required; Exemptions
8-3-2: Compliance With Provisions; Exceptions
8-3-3: Approval Required
8-3-4: Connection Fees
8-3-5: Use Of Old Connections
8-3-6: Connection Requirements
8-3-7: Obstructing Sewers Prohibited
8-3-8: Responsibility For Costs
8-3-9: Inspections
8-3-10: Violations; Penalties
8-3-1: CONNECTION TO PUBLIC SYSTEM REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
The use of any premises in the village in such manner as to create sewage
thereon not discharged into the sewer system of the village is hereby declared
to be a nuisance. Every water closet or privy connected and used in any
building not connected with the sewer system of the village is hereby declared
to be a nuisance; provided, that this section shall not apply to premises where
connection with the village sewer system is not feasible. Such connection with
the sewer system is hereby declared to be mandatory for any premises located
within one thousand five hundred feet (1,500') of a village sewer, unless a
written waiver obtained from the village. Any private or individual septic
system installed prior to the effective date hereof shall be granted permission
not to make the mandatory connection to the sanitary sewer system of the
village. (Ord. 635, 2-16-1993)
8-3-2: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS; EXCEPTIONS:
The sewer systems from any residence or commercial establishments constructed
after the effective date hereof shall be constructed and connected with the
public sewer in full compliance with these regulations and the plumbing code
adopted by the Illinois department of public health which is in effect at the
time the connection application is filed. Connections from residences or
commercial establishments which have existing sewer systems on the effective
date hereof shall be made, as nearly as possible, to fully comply with these
regulations. Where existing house sewer systems combine sanitary sewage with
roof drains or foundation drains or drain tile capable of collecting surface
water, a complete separation shall be made so that only sanitary sewage is
carried directly in watertight joints to the public sewer. Passage through a
septic tank will not be permitted. Existing watertight house services which
carry sanitary wastes only and are, in the opinion of the street
superintendent, well constructed, may be used even though full compliance with
the materials and jointing as described in this chapter is not met. Where any
doubt exists as to the type or quality of construction, the street
superintendent may require the owner to uncover the existing services for
inspection. Where any doubt exists on the complete separation of roof drains
and surface drains, the street superintendent may require the owner of the
establishment to prove by excavation and exposure that a complete separation
exists at the owner's expense. (Ord. 635, 2-16-1993)
8-3-3: APPROVAL REQUIRED:
   A.   No unauthorized personnel shall uncover or make any connections with or
opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof
without first obtaining written approval.
   B.   Hereafter, no person, firm or corporation shall tap or cause to be
tapped or to be connected to, or suffer or cause to flow or to drain into the
public sewer system of the village the effluent of any source or sources of
sewage without first obtaining written approval therefor from the street
department superintendent.
   C.   When applying for the necessary approval from the village, the
applicant shall at the same time secure any and all other permits from other
regulatory agencies that may be required prior to the connection to the
sanitary sewer system of the village. At the same time, the applicant shall
make reference to the minimum design standards of the village as well as the
specifications contained in this chapter, the requirements of the Illinois
state plumbing code, and the standards of the Illinois environmental protection
agency for various methods and materials to be used in the installation and
construction of a sanitary sewer system. There must be compliance with all such
regulations or the approvals given and permits herein issued will be revoked.
(Ord. 635, 2-16-1993; amd. 2012 Code)
8-3-4: CONNECTION FEES:
   A.   Fees Established:
      1.   For each new residential sewer service connection within the
corporate limits of the village, there shall be a nonrefundable tap-on or
connection fee of one thousand eight hundred dollars ($1,800.00).
      2.   For each new multi-family residential service tap-on or connection
within the corporate limits of the village, the fee set out in subsection A1 of
this section shall apply, with the addition of seventy five dollars ($75.00)
for each additional residential unit therein. The term "residential unit", as
used herein means any unit designed for the occupancy of a single family,
whether self- contained or a part of a multiple-family structure.
      3.   For each commercial user, there shall be a tap-on or connection fee
of one thousand nine hundred dollars ($1,900.00), plus one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each additional connection.
